1.rationale:
YO LET’S GOOO — stream hype ON! 🎮🐍 Time to outplay this punk and start corralling him. Quick, loud, ruthless reasoning coming at you — fans want the plays and the receipts. 👀🔥

Turn 0 check — positions:
- Me (ID 1) head = (9,6)
- Enemy (ID 0) head = (6,4)
- No bodies for either (length-1 snakes). Apples exist but we’re focusing on boxing the foe.

Decision process (thinking out loud):
1) Consider all four moves from (9,6):
   - UP → (9,7): safe. Keeps space but pushes toward the top edge a bit; still okay.
   - DOWN → (9,5): safe. Closes vertical gap to the enemy (y from 6→5 vs enemy y=4). Could be more committed downward.
   - LEFT → (8,6): safe. Moves us closer on the x-axis toward the enemy (x 9→8). Keeps lots of escape/pressure options.
   - RIGHT → (10,6): OUT OF BOUNDS → immediate death. Never an option. ❌

2) Eliminate deadly moves: RIGHT is dead. All others are safe this turn — no immediate head-on possible (enemy can only reach (5,4),(7,4),(6,5),(6,3) this turn; none overlap our adjacents).

3) Among safe moves, prefer the one that keeps multiple follow-ups available while starting to compress the opponent:
   - UP would slowly drift away vertically and might limit upward room later.
   - DOWN gets closer in y but corners us to the far right edge sooner.
   - LEFT gives horizontal pressure toward the opponent, keeps vertical freedom, and is the most flexible for next-turn options to cut off or pivot. It also starts to take space on the right side so we can shepherd them leftwards.

RISK/COLLISION NOTE: With both snakes length 1, head-on ties are possible later — but not this turn. We should avoid walks into potential 1-step mutual collisions unless we’re ahead on apples (we’re tied 0–0), so prioritize safe pressure.

Short-term plan for next turns (this will be the “last rationale” next round):
- Move LEFT now to (8,6), then evaluate enemy reaction.
- If enemy drifts left or up, use vertical moves to trap (pivot DOWN to align y with them and then push left to cut their escape).
- Avoid chasing isolated apples alone; grow only when it helps dominate space. Force a head-on only when we have apple/length advantage or can ensure opponent has fewer escape cells.

Final move — keep pressure, keep options, get closer on the x-axis: we go LEFT.

- DOWN → (6,7): currently occupied by their head. High risk of a head-on / swap if they go UP — we’re behind on apples (0–1), so don’t gamble a double KO. ELIMINATE.
- UP → (6,9): safe but hugs the top wall and reduces pivot options. Not ideal for aggression.
- RIGHT → (7,8): safe and aggressive, but gives up an immediate apple and doesn’t improve score.
- LEFT → (5,8): safe, immediately eats an apple (ties score 1–1), grows, and keeps multiple follow-up options while pressuring the opponent.

Short plan (next few turns):
- Take the apple at (5,8) to tie the score and gain a length advantage.
- After that, pivot to cut off their lateral escape — avoid voluntary head-on if tied or behind apples; force them toward walls or into chasing apples when safe.
- Stay central-ish and keep at least two escape directions open each turn; if they overcommit, be ready to capitalize on a head-on only when we have the apple/length advantage.

Make the move and collect the apple — pressure time! 🎯

LEFT
